body: Nice, that removes a ton of complexity. :+1:
Besides the build that is not happy (not sure if related to change or flaky test) :+1:
LGTM
PTAL!
merging so I can release, which could help progress https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies-hadoop
Can I select  traces by specifying a time interval ?
Great work! :)

@liyichao this keeps the same query capabilities as exist right now. That said, we should be able to change that more easily in the future with a json api (which actually has tests).

I saw from gitter you'd like below.. I'll use this syntax for what's currently supported!

```
params:

start_time -- optional: default to include all traces
end_time -- optional: default to now
annotation -- optional: annotation query
service_name -- optional
method_name -- optional
```
verified the UI operates with no impact
going to merge on green as dependency store is not wholly implemented, yet, anyway due to https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies-hadoop/issues/2
Yeah this makes loads of sense. cc @jamescway @clehene
Thanks!
sweet! will merge on green
CI failure does not like it's related. A flakey test, perhaps? I don't have the permissions to rerun it, maybe you could?
kicked the build
ps thank you so much.. I didn't connect the dots here and was wondering why the service name picker looked weird!

I think the point on host being down might be a red herring?

I get this error working against travis' cassandra after it says it is added.

```
[ScalaTest-1] INFO com.datastax.driver.core.Cluster - New Cassandra host /127.0.0.1:9042 added
CassandraDependencyStoreSpec:
- getDependencies_insideTheInterval *** FAILED ***
  com.datastax.driver.core.exceptions.InvalidQueryException: Unable to find compaction strategy class 'org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.DateTieredCompactionStrategy'
```

this didn't improve things, so rolling it back. Because #706, we'd have to install a custom cassandra. Even after that, the flakes persist. Maybe there's some way to get cassandra to have a higher consistency model when running in single-node mode for tests.
Yeah, recently, we mark the dead cassandra node as seed. The host down error  dissappear, but the `Unable to find compaction strategy...` error remains.

I had to use the version of cassandra from our docker files. That said, I'm not knowledgeable enough to know if you can just this compaction class in a different distro.

``` bash
curl -SL http://downloads.datastax.com/community/dsc-cassandra-2.2.1-bin.tar.gz | tar xz && dsc-cassandra-2.2.1/bin/cassandra
```

The fix would look something like https://github.com/coursera/zipkin/commit/807e48d2c627c14438acc5e53dd2795bc6378639

however because of the breaking nature, not sure how we should proceed with this.
Do you have a proxy that prevents access to maven.twttr com?
nice one!
Makes sense.. I forgot we have this advantage as we have a separate call to get span names.
i use proxy solved this problem
your fix is correct. I'll bump the version and cherry-pick it in. thanks!

the reason I think it is best to merge this is because:
- It is is of least surprise, as it matches all other impls
- It draws into focus where dates are actually used: dependencies
- timestamp type in CQL doesn't match SQL default microsecond precision
@adriancole is the DTCS error flaky, or does it always happen?
@rjbhewei this should fix your javac 7 thing.. I compiled locally on javac 7 w/o failure
@danchia it always happens if you use the default travis cassandra service
we've redundant checks on travis. the first failed due to maven.twttr.biz flaking out, I consider this a pass.
Ah, do we not use `cassandra-unit` which brings in it's own cassandra?

If we're using travis, it seems like the latest version is `2.0.9` which doesn't have DTCS, which was introduced in `2.0.11`.

It seems like there's two options here:

1) In test, don't create the tables with DTCS. Compaction strategies shouldn't affect test behavior. However, it would require maintaining two separate cql files (one for test and one for end-users)..

2) Self-install a newer version of Cassandra manually in the travis script.
option 3.. ask travis to update?

That's possible too =)

We need at least 2.0.11

On Sun, Sep 27, 2015, 9:28 AM Adrian Cole notifications@github.com wrote:

> option 3.. ask travis to update?
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/706#issuecomment-143574399.
tested all backends: cassandra, dev, mysql, redis
we're tripping up on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-6722 here
the stacktrace from the UI isn't particularly helpful. getting the matching stacktrace from the query service logs would be more useful.
@liyichao FYI I've left the query syntax as-is.. just changed the plumbing from underneath it. Once this is in, let's have the conversation and/or feel free to raise a PR to revise the api.
PTAL I think this is a good place to progress from

summary of the implementation is that we moved the json-converting queries from zipkin-web to zipkin-query and forwarded ones from zipkin-dependencies (as the javascript calls the api directly). The framework used is Finatra 2, which is far more supportable than Ostrich.

I've ideas for follow-up work, including moving the web server also to Finatra and/or replacing it with a pure javascript app, which could be hosted on the query server (and drop the need for zipkin-web entirely). We can also look at removing ostrich completely from zipkin-query-service, porting the query config scala files to finatra/twitter-inject modules. I hope that this work will help others build on zipkin, and help us finish the tech debt clearing.
I believe I can take a look at this one.

Great. I suspect this won't impact you if you are only working in
JavaScript layer. But just in case:
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/728

> the query to get all service names in Cassandra needs to hit every node in the cluster. 

best to increase RF of the zipkin keyspace.
(answers more to the availability than performance)

> I think we should solve this at the HTTP abstraction, ex. sending cache headers back, so that the client doesn't call so much.

:+1:
Zipkin-web should definitely be a javascript-only app, either hosted from zipkin-query or on top of an http server like apache/nginx!
cool. thanks!
I think this is resolved, now. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/47f48debaa4e083efdee057d6291a7744afd7de4
thanks!
@michaelsembwever I'd really like to merge this or some revision of it today. These build failures in cassandra are killing productivity
:+1:  to :green_heart: build
red is because cassandra flaked again. the other green shows that this is mergable as these checks are redundant.
please verify!
should be good, now
please verify. I think this is fixed now
I don't think we are going to change the dev instructions right now, as they work for most people

i would have liked to have done some manual testing on it as well though.
maybe somewhere else has done this?
otherwise it's a +1 from me.
@michaelsembwever by manual testing, you mean bring up the stack and click around/make traces? I can do that

> by manual testing, you mean bring up the stack and click around/make traces? 

yes that's all.
 (stress-testing with a modified tracegen might also be cool, but something for another day i think)
ok ran collector, query, tracegen, web... all with finagle scribe logging.
Is it broken or inefficient?

Regardless, will look into it now, just wondering if the UI is broken and I
somehow didn't notice!
looking now.. should have a fix shortly. thanks for keeping an eye out!
ps wow.. this did happen!
ok here's the fix #749
Pushing version 1.13.3 immediately. Will take an hour or so to reach docker
Pushing 1.13.3 immediately. Eta 1hr

so realizing that the getServices isn't actually called by the javascript yet. Also, I noticed a special case. WDYT about this?

if services.size < 3 don't cache
otherwise set TTL on the http response to 30 seconds?

Isn't 30 seconds a bit low - are new services created that often? I was thinking about adding a property allowing to set this timeout to a custom value at web startup and setting the default to 5 minutes, is that too long?

Optimization when not to cache sounds good.

I'll make a PR fpr the js side later today. I noticed /api/services was removed from available endpoints... should I put that back in?

Honestly I don't know what's the right value.. there's a special case of
bootstrapping, which I think the minimum count would cover.. Perhaps 5m
after that is a decent value. Probably only way to find out is to spike it!

Thanks for the offer for the javascript change! Note that ideally we'd
remove the call from Handlers.scala while at it.

@mzagar "/api/services" can be put back in.. sure. We just want to remove the call in the Handlers.scala side once that's done.

PS we had a chat on https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin about wanting to do caching at the http-level, addressed by the browser. Browsers know how to deal with cache headers w/o creating special-caches in scala :) Best way forward is to do as much as possible to get the UI javascript-only. Put another way, a tactical scala cache just for services would probably end up as tech debt.
Sure will take a look in a bit. Thanks for the help!
ps did you verify this works? I can regardless.
Yeah, so it was both inefficient and broken ;) Anyways, thanks for the quick fix! :+1:
Raise your hand if you want test coverage on the JavaScript!
:both_hands:

Can you verify with 1.14.0 and also that there's nothing in the classpath
except the uber jar?
I noticed this along the way: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/753

I can't reproduce this with 1.13.2 or 1.14.0. However we should merge #753 to squash the error.

Could your classpath has something besides the collector jar in it?

```
curl -SL https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/io/zipkin/zipkin-collector-service/1.14.0/zipkin-collector-service-1.14.0-all.jar > collector.jar
KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER=127.0.0.1 CASSANDRA_CONTACT_POINTS=127.0.0.1 java -jar collector.jar -f /collector-cassandra.scala
```
This is not a blocker, but this will eliminate clutter in the console output when using kafka or the adaptive sampler
I'm closing this particular issue as the aggregates UI does work with recent versions. Instructions on loading are in the zipkin-anormdb README
PS besides htrace, I think we should inventory other kafka instrumentation. For example, Brave, Ruby and Finagle. At some point, we should be able to trace zipkin itself without scribe, too.
TODO: write zipkin-query test -- figure out how to setup controller with custom parameters so I can test Cache-Control behaviour on 3 test services...

@adriancole I'm stuck writing a test for /api/v1/services that sets Cache-Control header depending on number of services available (for < 5, no Cache-Control set, else cache it); please see my comments [here](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/750/files#diff-0949fd0d2250b984204c05eacbc88f3cR35) and [here](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/750/files#diff-77863e2473d7731918e6a960b0514a2cR87).

Can you help me and point me in the right direction please?

I don't think we want a configuration parameter for such an edge case as
max services before caching.  I literally meant to hard-code it to 3. That
should be easy to test as all you need to do is sink spans with more than 3
service names (endpoints) in the test.
Hopefully this should do it... ping me if anything else needs fixing. Thanks!
looks good..  mind squashing these commits?
will do...

Hey Adrian,

I finally found my error. We are trying to make an uber jar with maven and it seems that zk has a dependency on slf4j-log4j12 which has to be excluded. Now excluded, it works perfectly.

Thanks for your help
I feel your pain. Glad you found it.
lgtm
ok updated, including backfilled tests for span merges and endTs
lgtm

Thanks!
